label: Community Alpha Â· Change Ringing
description: Plain hunt cycles for ordering tracks/parameters; rows are 1-based and wrap to rounds.

explanation.overview: Change ringing is a mathematical art form originating from English campanology (bell ringing). Each 'row' represents a permutation of elements where adjacent pairs swap positions in an alternating pattern.
explanation.mechanism: Starting from 'rounds' (1,2,3,4,...,N), each transition swaps adjacent pairs. The pattern continues until returning to the starting position, forming a complete cycle. This creates a deterministic, periodic sequence ideal for parameter automation.
properties: Cyclic: Always returns to starting position (rounds)
Minimal changes: Only adjacent elements swap between rows
Even parity: All permutations are even (determinant +1)
Smooth transitions: No element jumps more than one position at a time
explanation.applications: In BioSynCare, these sequences can modulate track parameters (frequency, gain, panning) creating smooth, cyclical variations. The predictable pattern provides structure while maintaining variety.
references: Campanology: Traditional English bell ringing mathematics
Group theory: Symmetric group Sn and adjacent transpositions

source.notes: Deterministic plain-hunt permutations; convert to 0-based indices for arrays.

sequences.label: Plain Hunt on 6
sequences.explanation: Six-element plain hunt pattern. Starting from rounds (1,2,3,4,5,6), adjacent pairs swap alternately through 12 changes before returning. With 6 bells, you can modulate up to 6 simultaneous track parameters in a coordinated cyclical pattern. Common in traditional bell ringing as 'Plain Bob Minor'.

sequences.label: Plain Hunt on 4
sequences.explanation: Four-element plain hunt pattern. Cycles through 8 distinct permutations before returning to rounds. Ideal for modulating a quartet of parameters (e.g., four audio tracks or two stereo pairs). Known in bell ringing as 'Plain Bob Minimus'. The smaller dimension creates faster cycling suitable for shorter sessions.
